We see in the columns of one of our recent issues that the
Athletic Association is to entertain both the Oxford-Cambridge
, and the Army lacrosse teams by large dances to be given the
night after each game.
This is the first time, we believe that such a thing has been
undertaken by the athletic authorities, and we wish them every
success. They have done everything in their power to make the
affairs attractive, limiting attendance to those connected with
the University, and setting the price of tickets at the nominal
figure of one dollar.
The easiest part remains for the students. In order to
support the project, and out of courtesy to the two teams that
are the high lights of the lacrosse schedule, every one who is
possibly able should make every effort to attend.

Pleasant breezes and warm sunlight succeeded last Thursday
in lulling the fears which the Dean's letter to Assembly cutters
had inspired in the minds of sophomores and freshmen; and
attendance at the weekly gathering again fell to a low ebb.
Those who felt the lure of the great open spaces missed a very
excellent contest for the Adams trophy, the winner of which. the
NEWS-LETTER wishes to heartily congratulate. It is our intention, however, not to discuss the shortcomings of those who
were absent on that particular day; but rather to consider very
briefly the whole question of Assemblies.
The suggestion has been advanced that attendance at Assemblies be made purely voluntary for the lower classes, as well
as for juniors and seniors. But the advocates of such a plan
seem to be making a mountain out of the proverbial mole hill.
ExcePt in rare instances, it does not seem possible that the
requirement to be in the C. E. Hall fifty minutes out of the
week can weigh heavily upon any but those supporters of the
theory of the inalienable right of the'college man to do as little
as possible who would spend two hours getting out of required
work which would require ten minutes. •
On the other hand, the advantage of this fifty minutes may
be very great. It is the one opportunity for the undergraduate
body as anything approaching a unit. It is the logical place
for undergraduate events of general interest and for announcements of the University authorities.
As for the addresses which usually take up most of the
time we cheerfully admit that they are sometimes tiresome, but
nevertheless we contend that they are a good thing. As a means
of keeping the student in touch with subjects beyond his small
list of required courses they are valuable. The practical engineer can desert his machinery, doff his overalls and attend a
lecture on the beauty of English verse; while the pallid student
of the classics will at some other time have the opportunity of
having Gas Engineering explained in terms that he stands
some chance of grasping. Such a diversity of topics is broad
.ening, especially when they lie outside the sphere of some of
the hearers. And in any particular instance when the subject
fails to awaken any intellectual response in a few indivduals,
it is always possible to slumber in an attitude of respectful
_attention..
Thus, whatever may be the weather conditions of the few
remaining Thursdays, the NEWS-LETTER hopes for a better response to the regulation on Assembly attendance.

the University, and setting the price of tickets at the nominal
figure of one dollar.

are the high lights of the lacrosse schedule, every one who is
possibly able should make every effort to attend.

Pleasant breezes and warm sunlight succeeded last Thursday
in lulling the fears which the Dean's letter to Assembly cutters
had inspired in the minds of sophomores and freshmen; and
attendance at the weekly gathering again fell to a low ebb.
Those who felt the lure of the great open spaces missed a very
excellent contest for the Adams trophy, the winner of which. the
NEWS-LETTER wishes to heartily congratulate. It is our intention, however, not to discuss the shortcomings of those who
were absent on that particular day; but rather to consider very
briefly the whole question of Assemblies.
The suggestion has been advanced that attendance at Assemblies be made purely voluntary for the lower classes, as well
as for juniors and seniors. But the advocates of such a plan
seem to be making a mountain out of the proverbial mole hill.
ExcePt in rare instances, it does not seem possible that the
requirement to be in the C. E. Hall fifty minutes out of the
week can weigh heavily upon any but those supporters of the
theory of the inalienable right of the'college man to do as little
as possible who would spend two hours getting out of required
work which would require ten minutes. •
On the other hand, the advantage of this fifty minutes may
be very great. It is the one opportunity for the undergraduate
body as anything approaching a unit. It is the logical place
for undergraduate events of general interest and for announcements of the University authorities.
As for the addresses which usually take up most of the
time we cheerfully admit that they are sometimes tiresome, but
nevertheless we contend that they are a good thing. As a means
of keeping the student in touch with subjects beyond his small
list of required courses they are valuable. The practical engineer can desert his machinery, doff his overalls and attend a
lecture on the beauty of English verse; while the pallid student
of the classics will at some other time have the opportunity of
having Gas Engineering explained in terms that he stands
some chance of grasping. Such a diversity of topics is broad
.ening, especially when they lie outside the sphere of some of
the hearers. And in any particular instance when the subject
fails to awaken any intellectual response in a few indivduals,
it is always possible to slumber in an attitude of respectful
_attention..
Thus, whatever may be the weather conditions of the few
remaining Thursdays, the NEWS-LETTER hopes for a better response to the regulation on Assembly attendance.
